subject: Re: [junit] Reusable TestSuite facilities.
msgSnippet: ... I would make it a public, class-level field of the one-time setup class. ... If the method is going to be class-level, then the field it writes to also has
messageBody:
mark_l_salter wrote:
>
>
> I am attempting to construct a test suite that has a common component
> referenced and used from within tests in the suite, which is set-up
> once.
>
> The 'common' component is a network connection to a remote server
> (under test). The important aspect (to me) for the majority of tests
> is not the connection, but getting a number of messages into and back
> from the remote system. I am in the position of being able to predict
> what response the remote system should give for a particular request.
> I feel the connection establishment and management can (and should?)
> be tested separately.
>
> What I can't see is where to put the 'common' object and how to
> reference it from a test level. I feel like I am missing the obvious,
> and probably it's java rather than JUnit related!

I would make it a public, class-level field of the one-time setup class.

> import junit.framework.*;
> import junit.extensions.TestSetup;
>
> public class AllTestsOneTimeSetup {
>
> Connection c = null;
>
> public static Test suite() {
>
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>
> suite.addTest(SomeTest.suite());
> suite.addTest(AnotherTest.suite());
>
> TestSetup wrapper = new TestSetup(suite) {
>
> protected void setUp() {
> oneTimeSetUp();
> }
>
> protected void tearDown() {
> oneTimeTearDown();
> }
> };
>
> return wrapper;
> }
>
> public static void oneTimeSetUp() {
> // one-time initialization code
>
> c = new Connection("remoteIP");

If the method is going to be class-level, then the field it writes to
also has to be class-level. That's fundamental Java, as you suspected.
:)
